name: NewYorker
text: Raising a glass to The New Yorker legend—born ﬁve years before the founding of this magazine, and a contributor for the past 76—as he celebrates a milestone birthday. https://t.co/jt8gACc5Os

name: NewYorker
text: Kim Flitcroft’s 1995 documentary, “Tales from a Hard City,” tells the story of three young people aspiring to—and struggling to achieve—careers as performers, whose participation in the film is itself a means to their end. https://t.co/A9ahEYfLAT

name: NewYorker
text: “There’s still plenty of money to be made in art, or writing, or music,” @huahsu writes. “It’s just not being made by the creators.” https://t.co/lI4t8zxzqm

name: NewYorker
text: “Christ’s sakes, Casper. The advert was in the back pages of a gay magazine. For a houseboy. It’s hardly the employment office.” New fiction by @Doug_D_Stuart. https://t.co/UsRRMpZwQd

name: NewYorker
text:
The conceptual artist Bernadette Mayer's “Memory" may be from 1971, but its nostalgia for summers lost speaks uncannily to our moment.
https://t.co/XCyljN2AP8

name: NewYorker
text: “Someday you’ll feel thankful to your mother. But I want you to act thankful now.” Listen to Susan Choi read her new short story. https://t.co/vhMaLHgeOx

name: NewYorker
text: “I think that when people loot during a riot, they are solving a lot of the immediate problems that make their lives very, very hard," the author of “In Defense of Looting” says, in a conversation with @IChotiner. https://t.co/Lfdks4UzY9

name: NewYorker
text: In the pandemic, there will be an outdoor season and an indoor season, Paul Elie writes. Spring, summer, fall, and winter will be vestigial presences, which we encounter in music, poetry, and movies more than in our everyday lives. https://t.co/RkHKTokDci

name: NewYorker
text: It is simply incredible that many professional athletes have violated their contracts, withdrawn their labor, and demanded that this country change, @KeeangaYamahtta writes. https://t.co/oclpb6yGXs

name: NewYorker
text: In the spring, when the ice thaws in one of the northernmost villages in Greenland, some of the community's Inuit members begin to hunt narwhal. A new film peers into the tradition. Watch here. https://t.co/PbEdqdEI0V

name: NewYorker
text: Why were the killers of Ahmaud Arbery allowed to walk free until the shooting became a national scandal? And what does the failure to prosecute say about the power of district attorneys? #NewYorkerRadio https://t.co/V1kTQitv2g

name: NewYorker
text: In the summer and autumn of 2016, Nick Neely walked from San Diego to San Francisco Bay—a 650-mile trek. Neely's book about the journey, “Alta California,” touches on many layers of California’s fiendishly complex history. https://t.co/oH35JlWX0B

name: NewYorker
text:
We get a sense of what a warming globe feels like—each second, trapping the heat equivalent to four Hiroshima-sized bombs exploding—when we have a week like the one we just came through.
https://t.co/xpiBumtqoQ

name: NewYorker
text: The idea of gentrifying a sound may seem odd, but sound is one of TikTok’s greatest assets—and it is being mined to widen a gap between white poachers and Black originators, @jiggyraps writes. https://t.co/hM73kwemwS

name: NewYorker
text: Even as President Alexander Lukashenka continues to crack down on opposition, the writer Svetlana Alexievich does not plan to flee Belarus. “I don’t want people to lose the last remaining hope. So I’m going to be here to the end,” she said. https://t.co/TFK1K7qbTw

name: NewYorker
text: Minutes before her mother's nursing facility kicked its patients' aides out, @JiayangFan was on FaceTime with her, desperately trying to reassure her. "It was then that I took the screenshots that later spread across Chinese social media," Fan writes. https://t.co/9lSHSniYVk

name: NewYorker
text:
In a series of iPhone photographs taken over the course of two and a half years, Jeff Mermelstein captures the quotidian dramas taking place on the phone screens of unsuspecting strangers.

https://t.co/BQY1YPZODX

name: NewYorker
text: "Anybody who knows me knows that I want to do right by everyone, so to learn that my actions—specifically, eating humans—were ever at anybody’s expense makes my heart hurt." https://t.co/JUKDFnmvyi

name: NewYorker
text: A new translation of one of the oldest surviving works of literature consists of passages of sublime poetry punctuated by social-media shorthand. https://t.co/lwA9yP5Nbn

name: NewYorker
text: A new documentary chronicles a water park's expansion from a go-kart track and a few small water slides to a full-on amusement park that boasted dicey thrills with very little oversight. https://t.co/LxdAnoIg94

name: NewYorker
text: The New York attorney general is investigating whether the Trump Organization inflated the value of Donald Trump’s assets to obtain more favorable loan terms or understated them to reduce tax treatment. https://t.co/4XTRI6uwQg

name: NewYorker
text:
Dexter Filkins discusses how Republicans have been suppressing Democratic votes to turn Florida from a swing state into a G.O.P. stronghold. Listen here, or wherever you get your podcasts. #NewYorkerRadio
https://t.co/W4pIJNMdJ2

name: NewYorker
text: Throughout the 20th century, federal policy focussed on putting out fires as quickly as possible. But preventing megafires requires a different approach. https://t.co/YsPt4qQdeS

name: NewYorker
text: "The problem isn’t that people are not the way they used to be," @Atul_Gawande writes. "It’s that the economy and the structure of work are not the way they used to be." https://t.co/GAPbjIobH6

name: NewYorker
text: “I’m Thinking of Ending Things” evokes self-consciousness from behind a screen of impersonality—self-awareness without the self. https://t.co/tIQ7Mkb5M9

name: NewYorker
text: Nina Compton wanted to succeed as a chef not only for the sake of personal fulfillment but as an act of defiance against a society rigged against Black achievement. Now she is facing the coronavirus crisis. https://t.co/3NYnB8Ej1k

name: NewYorker
text: "How is it that the world keeps going, breathing in and out unchanged, while in my soul there is a permanent scattering?" @ChimamandaReal remembers her father, who died suddenly this summer, in the family’s ancestral home town, in Nigeria. https://t.co/xl3SnJPCtw

name: NewYorker
text: “If Donald Trump possessed a soul, a trace of conscience or character, he would resign,” David Remnick writes, of the appalling Presidency described in lurid detail in Bob Woodward’s new book. https://t.co/JXMOwfiO02

name: NewYorker
text: Due to recent shifts in government messaging, the objective is now to move around the board as much as possible and stimulate the economy without losing property or dying. https://t.co/5gqpoN87rI

name: NewYorker
text: A cartoon by @zoesees. https://t.co/sEDUplljVq

name: NewYorker
text: The star of Disney’s live-action "Mulan" contracted the coronavirus after travelling to the cancelled London première. Now he’s home in Hawaii, tending to his family and his overgrown garden. https://t.co/Pzjx4UJ0wY

name: NewYorker
text: “I’m here, in the present, in a ravaged America, watching two men in England, 30 years in the past, who are tending a garden more than a century old—very gently, and with great care, coaxing it back to life,” @hels writes. https://t.co/l9YA1LEpwV
